As more than 1,0000 students staged walkouts for a second day on Friday over tougher national immigration policies, one Dallas ISD trustee wants to make clear that all kids are welcome and safe at school. 
Next week the board will consider a resolution by trustee Jaime Resendez that says DISD educates all children, regardless of immigration status. 
âItâs a show of support,â said Resendez, an attorney and Iraq war veteran who's the son of Mexican immigrants. âTo me, itâs the right thing to do for our students and our city and our country.â 
More than 1,000 students from several Dallas ISD schools walked out of classes Friday, according to district officials and Facebook videos. Those campuses include eight high schools â Sunset, Spruce, Skyline, Kimball, South Oak Cliff, North Dallas, Conrad and W.T. White â and one middle school, Tasby. Students who missed class would have been marked as unexcused, district officials said. 
Arlington ISD reported a few hundred students walking out at five schools. 
On Thursday, more than a thousand DISD students either walked out or didnât come to school, spurred by a national âDay Without Immigrantsâ protest. The districtâs student attendance rate was 85 percent Thursday, down from 95 percent on Wednesday. 
When students are absent, school districts can lose state money. And, of course, the students lose time in the classroom. 
âI would prefer our students to be in class and take every opportunity to learn,â Resendez said. âBut if they chose to take a stand in that manner, thatâs their prerogative.â 
Resendezâs resolution would be largely symbolic. The U.S. Supreme Court ruled in 1982 that states canât deny children a free public education based on their immigration status. Dallas ISD District 4 candidate Jaime Resendez pictured April 6, 2016 in Dallas, Texas. Staff Photographer 
Still, Resendez said, heâs heard from students, parents and teachers in DISD and beyond that many kids worry about their parents or other loved ones being deported. President Donald Trump has announced orders and policies aimed at stricter enforcement of immigration laws. 
About 70 percent of DISDâs 158,000 students are Hispanic. The district does not track the percentage of students who are unauthorized immigrants. 
Several other large districts, including Houston ISD and San Antonio ISD , have passed similar resolutions. Austin ISD is considering one as well. 
In California, the stateâs education chief recently urged school districts there to declare themselves safe havens, according to news reports. Hundreds of students protest, dozens of businesses close in Dallas for 'A Day Without Immigrants' strike 
School districts arenât the only ones declaring theyâre havens. Dallas County passed a resolution this month that calls for local law enforcement to end ânonessential collaborations" with federal immigration officials. 
Both Trump and Gov. Greg Abbott have called for crackdowns on so-called sanctuary cities and counties â a loosely defined term thatâs become explosive for some politicians. They can be places that shelter unauthorized immigrants by not cooperating with federal immigration authorities. But others argue that federal immigration authorities are largely those charged with enforcing immigration laws. Texas Senate approves measure to cut funds for sanctuary cities 
The approach that the proposed Dallas ISD resolution lays out âis not only appropriate but probably mandatoryâ under federal law, said Thomas Saenz, president and general counsel for the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, a nonprofit civil rights group. 
When it comes to public schools, Saenz said, âOur interpretation has always been you must provide a safe haven.â
